entry.title: Chapter 6: Connecticut Border
entry.content:
Chapter 6: Connecticut Border

We rush along to the lot, more of a junkyard if we’re lacking tact
With cars, robots, drones, cranes and all types of machinery disassembled
The clock blares again, and over a loudspeaker we hear
A shrill voice leading a mantra with demonic undertones
“Chosen ones, find it in your heart to stamp out hate at any cost
Your life, their life, one in the same, is proper blood spilled
Those fallen before you, were culled as they should be.”
I shiver, appalled by what I’ve heard
The care for human life on par with that of a gulag
“That’s your cue my boy to get out of this state.
By nightfall the streets teem with infernal practicing
Of extracurriculars in hopes of finding in-flesh hosts and moments of reckoning.”

Like leaving a long lost family member
My farewell cuts deeper than I expected
“Thanks aren’t enough
As you saved me from certain torment—
Flying solo, I’d have met my maker”
I help him hoist a tarp revealing five obscure vehicles
He winks, “just because I look Victorian—
Does not mean I have not learned to get my hands dirty.”

“Be swift, and take 90 to the west
Your road gets brighter, I’m sure, when you hit Connecticut
For me I’m back to the haunted train where we first met
As something tells me there’s more like you to come
To witness the chaos of this century”

I choose the most obscure car on the lot
But still I cannot go—
No pedal, brake, nor steering wheel.
My guide just grins—
Tossing me the keys, and pressing the ignition
A robotic voice hums—
“Destination please?”
Not sure where to go, I blurt out the first place in my mind,
“Krispy Pizza, Brooklyn, New York City”
The machine pauses. Waiting…
“No current match found—
Redirecting to coordinates last archived in 2055”

Before I can ask if New York met a similar demise
The car whirs away
And him again
Just a silhouette in my mirror
Avoiding pothole madness in a reverse game of whack-a-mole
MassDOT obviously disappeared with the tightening of the purse
But who could blame them—
If everyone left
Leaving this thoroughfare so hauntingly empty

Eventually 90 became 84 and I head southwest
To a state border crossing, the first of the journey—
This one, purposefully ominous
Miles of abandoned vehicles and trailers, glowing with neon lights
Gargoyles perched on road-signs
Grotesque tongues as long as their limbs
A fair warning to those not welcome—
“You’d best turn around.”

Still I press along confident in my intent
Unencumbered by regulations existing in this new world
When suddenly—
My vehicles comes to a standstill
Not even a screech from the brakes
The whiplash from the seatbelt—
A reminder I’m not at my own behest

A border patrolman comes out, inching closer, a rifle abreast
Surveying me and my vehicle—
Whether I’m any type of threat
A bright light flashes from his pocket
Too soon for me to shield my eyes
And he yells with assertion, “State your destination.”
My hands clam up, my brow lined with sweat
“Oh dear god, what do I say?
It’s true
I’m just passing through
But is that information sufficient?”
“New York City sir, to visit a cousin for a reunion”
Hoping my intuition works to keep my matters short and sweet.
The guard’s face grows stern as he approaches nearer
Followed by a beep from his device—
Like a machine whirring on in error
“You’re not in the national database
Now cut out the lies.
And if you don’t, I’m trained to assume—
You’re a Northern spy
With your crime being treason”

Solemn and pale I have no comeback to offer
I feebly hand him my wallet as he starts shuffling through it
His anger turned to confusion as he started uncovering its contents
White knuckling an expired stack of credit cards
“What is the point of counterfeiting artifacts so obtuse?”
Until the final card he unveils immediately uplifts his tune
A card— I sometimes forget—
That has been in my possession for years
It reveals an ode to a land of steep cliffs
Enveloped in fog
With a blessing of hope
In deep times of need

In sudden revelation his world view turns on its axis
His scowl morphs into a shape far less obscene
He steps back, his rifle withdrawn
A moment of longing etched on his face
He closes his eyes
Muttering something in deep contemplation
“Its so rare these days to see relics of faith in these northern parts
And coupled with these plastic relics,
Who am I to discern?
Perhaps you’re a ghost, a vision, a hallucination, or just a fraud with a printer
But deep-down something whispers, that I have no right to apprehend you
Be quick, the cameras absolutely monitor everything
I’ll wipe the data I can, but I’m lost as to each iota that they scan.”
“Maybe they have my neck for it, but who am I to judge?
Like our state’s great hero, I now feel grounded in my conviction.”
“Thank you” I sigh
Lost for words after his benevolence
“But you keep that one for safety as a token of my appreciation”

Just like that, I crawl through the archway
Careful about my speed
Praying for gladder tidings ahead
And a more welcoming landscape
“May the road rise up to meet you
May the wind always be at your back
May the sun shine warm upon your face
And rain fall soft upon your fields
And until we meet again, may God
Hold you in the palm of His hand.”

End of Chapter 6
entry.summary: The traveler leaves Massachusetts and crosses into Connecticut

entry.title: Chapter 5: Cambridge
entry.content:
Chapter 5: Cambridge

We march on towards Revere’s house
Twisting and turning between the grey streets and debris
Masterfully evading caws and chants from the North End procession

And his house, what a sight to behold!
The dwelling of America’s first hero
Unscathed and untouched by the chaos surrounding it all

So I ask
“How’s it in pristine condition?
Even the tombstones are untouched.
It feels impossible, given everything else I’ve seen.”

“An astute observation – you’ll know soon enough
Fortunately, some semblance of intelligent good
Still has regard for the sacred.”

My guide looks over his shoulder
As we inch nearer the entry
The crowd still loud, but comfortably out of sight
He neatly picks the lock, the man’s done this before
He swings the door open, ushering me
Into the pitch black greeting us in the catacomb

My guide moves gracefully
As if led by some cosmic sonar
He opens a trap door that emits neon green light
He beckons me on, punching through my stiff apprehension
I follow – guided by his certainty
Once again down into the pits

“Put these on” he commands
Throwing a wardrobe of revolutionary attire my way
I buckle my shoes – the clicking I find quite satisfying
The heavy wool itches, a scratch I cannot reach
Yet oddly – I feel blanketed in its comfort

“This tunnel leads to the other side of the Charles
And we’ll cross to a neighborhood
Unrecognizable to any of your day
Cambridge, my dear Cambridge and its orchestrated malevolence!
Fomented by no oversight or regulation
I press as to why–
“What’s Cambridge’s role in all this?
The Universities lost their pull in my time
Grasping at any straw they could”

He paused to collect his thoughts
Prepping his response
“Everything, my dear boy
Now let me tell you why”

“That downtown you saw is merely a testing ground
To train saboteurs
Rioting, looting, gearing up for the day
They enact the same travesties on a scale hundredfold”

“You see, the commonwealth got desperate
The pulse of a city and state dying under the weight of its debt
And the Universities – yes you were correct – they were in a bind
In their own dire state of affairs
Desperate for students, anyone who’d pay the price
But Harvard and MIT – being well endowed – rode the bumpy waters
And didn’t stop there”

“They made a deal with the state
Leasing city blocks to do what they pleased
Scooping up street after street until each inch was theirs
They curated a playground for students
With their minds trapped in infancy
A stunted doctrine – with personal development irrelevant”

He pauses a moment, massaging the cold tunnel wall
Looking for something to pull
He finds a latch and out springs a ladder
Up he is instantly – and me
Tuckered out in my wool costume, barely able to keep up

Off with a manhole cover
The sun shining through enough to blind
As it bounces off a brilliant metal
Only such a material –
Could rays catch and disarm us so

Now on Cambridge proper
Perhaps I was better off staying beneath the streets
Staring aghast at a mighty chrome structure
A fortress – building no more – a laboratory
Built out of anger

And the rubble that it displaced
Each brilliant hall, hundreds of years old
Not even a mere afterthought
To a once decent society

My guide shakes his head
“I avoid these shores as often as I can
Seeing what they did to marvelous architecture
It gets me every time.”

“In desperate moments is when the devil brings out his best tricks
A teetering endowment, a crumbling state–
The most dastardly of synergies”

“It was meant to be temporary
But grew unwieldy
Unlimited popularity to practice destruction with no consequence
Could not be passed up by the bursar”

“So Harvard and MIT fused and grew as one
The ideologues and the tech
Admitting anyone willing to pay full price
Blinded by their avarice
Embracing their new roles–
Provocateurs on the eastern shore

“Wait, wait, wait,” I interrupt
“What’s the point? University to learn chaos?
That’s all this boils down to?”

He takes a second, clarifying his thoughts

“Yes but lest you forget, brilliant minds are alive and well
Misguided, certainly, but overcome the apprehension by a drive
To test boundaries of what’s possible
The one percenters get funneled into the usual suspects
Big tech, banking, diplomacy, shady NGOs
While the lemmings down in the streets are thrown into the bureaucrat grinder.”

“Its survival depends on its horrid mutation
Even Faust would cringe
Students groomed with no independent thought
Or agency to stand alone on the mountain

We walk up to an iron barricade
Fortified walls preventing us seeing the inside
Bells ringing to usher a door open
As a student procession files out

“Watch this,” my guide winks to me
Confidently strutting towards a crew thirty strong

Not even ten meters near them does he make it
Before a barrage of insults are thrown his way
Much of the slander was gibberish to me
Revolutionary apologists– how is that even a thing?
Though I find it funny– fascist is still in vogue
I guess some things never do change

Their jeers egg my guide on
His soapbox growing higher by the second
He breaks into soliloquy about Thomas Paine
The hollering grows an octave higher
After a minute of his comic dialogue
He bows deep– wipes the spit from his brow
Turning away from their sneers without a second look

“Ha, good fun, gotta stay entertained in some shape or form,
Fortunately the code of conduct here states–
No harm done north of the Charles in the light of day”

As an explosion deafens us
South across the water from where we stand
“Though the poor souls caught–
In the wrong crosshairs over there
Well, lucky for you that you found me”

Glad to be standing next to a new friend
I sense our time is coming to an end
As if he’s reading my mind he ushers me forward
“Come there’s nothing left for you in Boston to see
As much as I’d love to show you inside this new fortress
You’d guess right that security is indeed tight
Though all for naught the exercise would be
Us being just ghosts outside of their databases”

“Keep on, I’ll get you south
A whole country is left for you to explore
One, I’ll add, not for the faint of heart
But the pockets of goodness will make it
Absolutely worth your while.”

“Just as Revere’s house stands tall
It takes benevolence and a fighting spirit
To deploy the right tech for the right reasons
Holding onto a glimmer of hope
For what this country once stood for.”

He hurried down the street
Waving me along to follow
Just as a bell tower struck five times
Signalling a classic Northeast early autumn sundown

End of Chapter 5
entry.summary: The traveler explores Cambridge and prepares to leave Massachusetts

entry.title: Chapter 4: Boston
entry.content:
Chapter 4: Boston

Thunderous eruption slaps heavily from above
I wake to chanting and cursing
Banging on windows, pure savagery about
A full array of colorful use of the tongue
A mob without scruples
No use in questioning
Its intent to wreak havoc

The railcar is ironclad
Quite the haven at the end of it all
But surely the sanctuary fades away
As soon as its black doors screech open

And a voice!
“Up now! Come quickly!”

I shoot up, as if laying on hot coals
To come face to face with the silhouette figure
Who was no figment of my deep dream space

So peculiar, a man dressed in such antiquated garb
At such an age
Was able to maneuver with such grace
He pushes open passenger doors
Ushering me forward
His speed had purpose, he had to have known
What was on the other side of the barricade

The train creaks to a stop
The doors crack open
Yells bellow from the back of the train
My guide pulls me out into blackness, out onto tarmac
Safe for now, I hope
From the madness we just escaped

“Through the hatch, come on up we go”
How did he even see there was a ladder?
Gripping each rung for dear life
I follow in sheer obedience

With effortless ease, a manhole cover
He hoists over his head
We climb out onto the street above
Dead center in what could only be described as a military drill

Sirens and blarehorns add to the fury
Detonators fire off with brutal precision
Smoke fills up all gaps
Along with every nook and cranny previously left with clean air

“I know this place
Many of times I walked these roads”
I thought, pondering where I was

“Fanueil Hall, my boy”
My guide says, with a pinch of despair
Just as I was coming to my own recollection of happy youthful memories

A beautiful brick building it was
But now, just art exhibit gone mad
A spit in the face of our earliest forefathers
The graffitied walls paying their sacrifices no mind

Robots, though, oddly enough
Equipped to do nothing but scrub paint from the masonry
Teemed the building, working with extreme precision

All for naught, so it would seem
As tomorrow the same vulgarity would be right back on the brick

I turn back to my rescuer
Deeply confused
By him, this city, this entire exercise!
He understands
And we exchange a quick glance that is deeply and truly comforting

He gave a deep bow before he spoke again
With the words and tone of a man from a bygone era:

“Not often my son do men escape the train from up north
Good that I found you to avoid certain unpleasantries
While dutybound I am to check the stations periodically
It’s a stroke of luck, I was there at that precise point and time”

“I see your fear, your confusion
You’re certainly not one of these modern men
Tell me then, strange traveler
What has compelled you to make the perilous journey
From that forsaken Hampshire station?”

How to answer?
So obvious a question it seemed
Too obvious, in fact, every answer would be deemed imperfect

Still I try:
“I’m figuring it out, poorly, I’m not gonna lie
But I gotta tell you..
Getting here was wild, dreamlike almost
But this, it feels all so visceral
It shocks me even more to see a black drape thrown over a once amazing city”
He sighs briefly,
“Your observation about my tormented home,
It couldn’t cut deeper.
I stand before you with great dismay
Bound to walk these obscure streets night and day”

“Mayor I once was, way before your time
I made a deal to survive politically
Awry my bargain went
Vanquished, then banished, and now–
Brought back as penance to lament what my Massachusetts has become”

“Hundreds of years ago there was turmoil abound
Our young nation was on the ropes
Barely clinging for survival
So I assembled New England’s finest - in Hartford one winter
To determine our states’ fate, even a new path to self sufficiency”

“A pragmatist I ultimately was
Perhaps I should have been more fierce in my youthful resolve
And followed the notions of my brethren
Who were far more hellbent”

“I look up to the North and see
How New Hampshire and Maine sealed their fate
In hardship,
But purpose,
In building their own nation state.”

Tears well in his eyes and I feel his pain
Unaware, sadly, of how to provide any comfort
So I nod with a genuine tone of acceptance
Sharing a calm moment of silence

For a moment I can smell the salty ocean air
A breeze to make Ishmael blush
Hearkening me back to wine, good food, and chowder
Oh chowder so hot, but so good, you don’t care that you burn your tongue

BANG
BANG
BANG!
Bass drums - pounding erupts near the North End
Chants are volleyed through the streets
Growing louder as a procession approaches nearer

Shaken to his senses, my guide eyes me from head to toe:
“No no, this will not do
Look at your attire - you stick out like a sore thumb.
That’s no pleasant chant you hear
But a dutiful legion of my dear Harvard’s current crop of miscreants.”

“And my garb, ha!
I fit in just fine, one perk of the sign of the times,
I blend as an outlier might, when crazy is the day’s litmus test.
Here, take my hat to start
It gives you at least a bit of cover
Until we get to Revere’s house and can fit you out properly.”

“From there we head to Cambridge
A town once of crimson, now of iron and steel
Back into the tunnels we go, best to avoid the lunatics training downtown
You must witness the administrators that now own my University and city”

End of Chapter 4
entry.summary: The traveler learns about the Boston's demise and its position in shaping US dystopia

entry.title: Chapter 3: The Border Train
entry.content:
Chapter 3: The Border Train

Its a dream
It has to be
There’s no other way
This railcar cannot exist, I mean–
Look at the years
2060, 70, 80, 2090!
The newspapered windows reveal
Troubled stories through and through
Surely for the most niche reader base

Yet one article
Quickly catches my eye
By a man named Krzyz
Published in 2069

I skim the first paragraph
Absurd wouldn’t begin to describe it
Declaring how lost souls, including his own
Can fall off the spacetime landscape

Tiny tremors pulse deep inside my chest
I scoff and dismiss the theoretical pseudo physics
Though I am compelled—
By a reason I cannot describe
To take the clipping, and fold it into my jean pocket

The train crawls on
Surely I could walk faster
My idle body lost in the vast solitude
Of my deepest fears and anxieties
The dim lights barely help
Initiating a bone chilling exhaustion
And a rest overcoming me, one which—
I’m terrified if I’ll even wake

I cannot resist further
As I’m brought to luminal sleep
When I’m suddenly shaken by a voice
In an accent I know
But never hear

“Hola mi amor
You know me, though you don’t realize it
I’ve been with you since the beginning
The half that keeps you going relentlessly”

“It was me, planting your wild ideas, foolish ones too
Camping on peaks not meant for travelers—
La Cabarga, Izoard, Angliru—
There I was for you”

“I’m your Athena, your Penelope, even your Calypso
Barricaded deep by ego for so long
Rendered to the ghost in our hardware
Combing through the darkest layer of our shadow”

“I’ve broken through
Your mind is primed to believe
In lands beyond the present
And the discoveries we’ll unveil together
We cannot retreat
Too deep into the fray we have come
In fact, how could we, when there’s nowhere to turn back to?
That’s why the Krzyz article compelled you so deeply—
Twists and turns
No start
No finish
Just a trail of crumbs to push us on”

What the hell is happening?
Surely there’s evil tricks aboard on this train
I—

“You’re thinking too much, mi amor
You’ve always failed at that
We’ll trudge through eternal mud
With that narrow and rational attitude of yours
The world’s greatest among us tap into the unknown
And if they have the fortitude to swim in murky waters
That is when the universe reveals its greatest gifts”

“I know you too well, ha!
You’d never be able to do this alone
So—
Do you trust me, to place your faith strongly
In something real for the first time in years?”

My chest tightens, her words pierce like a dagger to my gut
She’s right, I know it—
Years wasted giving into foolish pride
Vulnerability smeared across my face
But why now? —

“STOP again!
Don’t think too much
There’s never a right time to take the plunge
If I need to spoonfeed it to you
Fine, I guess that’s what it takes
A baby step first, to stay on this train”

Yes, I can do that, I will do that
I get it now—
What feels like a lifetime ago
When we threw caution to the wind
Responsible only for ourselves
Chance felt like a guarantee
A winner’s swagger that has been lost

“I foresee it now your confidence growing
With each passing day—
Until we’re thinking in unison
Our thoughts indecipherable from one another”

My body begins to warm
A blanket nestled upon my thoughts
As the sublime state
Between conscious and dreams tugs me down—
For a final deep sleep

As I close my eyes thinking of the journey ahead
My mind plays one last trick
Conjuring a silhouette at the front of the railcar

End of Chapter 3
entry.summary: The traveler experiences a mystical encounter aboard the train

entry.title: Chapter 2: The Train Ride
entry.content:
Chapter 2 - The Train Ride

My mysterious guide was right

With no guards in sight
I began my long desolate walk to the Merrimack
The North’s Rio Grande, Two Civilizations divided
By what, I still don’t know
Or if I even want to find out

To my dismay, I may not even have a choice
Upon seeing a fiery mountain shooting up plumes
Of smoke, exhaust, and the worst types of fumes
A pile of abandoned railcars, left undoubtedly as a tomb
Warning posts all around, telling defiant ones,
WE SHOOT ON SIGHT
Mass graves for the unlucky ones – who simply wanted out

Not even knowing how to turn back, I continue on in a rush
As a rickety railcar approaches, graffitied back to front
Hissing like a snake, seducing me to step on in

Captained by ghosts, how could this train be not?
And me? Do I fit the bill of such a bone-chilling prophecy?
I drum up the courage and enter the car furthest in the back

Newspapered windows, flickering lights, painted messages in languages illegible
I sit and try to gauge the editorials and what they may elucidate
The years are random 2030, 2040, all the way up to the late 2090s
No real news so to speak – opinion pieces catering to the niches
Not a surprise, journalism has always been a casualty to one click hysteria

Though one pieces catches my eye by a New Yorker named Lacroix
Shouting absurdities about spacetime wrinkles
Published in 2073
Suggesting there are those walking among us with answers from different times

I clutch at a sharp pain in my chest
Reading his words
Memories flooding back with a gigantic gap in between,
This present and my present, do I really know where I stand?
Atoning for some misdeed, required answers, or just a hallucination?

My conscious mind won’t let me think this is anything but a dream
Is this railcar, now picking up steam,
a wicked trick from deep in my psyche?
Who am I to say, as I begin to feel a longing
For wife, kids, and family lost at some other point in time

And then, a voice cautiously whispers deep in my right ear
Soothing me in an accent I know but never hear
“Please put your faith in me,
Far too long rationality has dominated your thought
Eschewing eons of years of progress to render Yourself down
To only what you can see”

“Fraught with destruction the course you’re on,
Only by losing yourself will you ultimately be found
The chaos engulfing you is immaterial
Its not part of your synchronicity
Deep down you know what to do,
For once, I beg, trust your iron will and instinct”

And like a punch to my heart and soul
It revives me for this heavy weight bout
Ready to step into the ether
And whatever it may hold

Alas, there’s no rest for the weary
As I’m suddenly woken by screams, whistles, and chants
Inside a station, I hadn’t realized we’d pulled in

Like a rapture banging on the door, it’d have shaken Peter to his core
Declarations to take no prisoners by the assailants at large
Yet here I am, the only one!

And like an olive branch extended from the front of the car
A cloaked figure grabs me by my sweaty hand, shouting
“Quickly. Follow me”

End of Chapter 2
entry.summary: The traveler takes a mysterious train from the New Hampshire border down to Boston

entry.title: Chapter 1: The Arrival
entry.content:
Chapter 1: The Arrival

Decades passed
As far as I could tell
Head pounding
Heart racing
Feet stuck to the ground

At the base of a mountain,
Capped with dirty wet snow
Teeming with moose, wolves, and beasts of all kind
They observe, unbothered by my presence

The lone road ground down to the bone
Offset by the intricate barbed wire
Guiding the full stretch of the shoulder

Dread creeps in of my unwanted presence
Rifling blood down to my legs, as I wander away
I arrive at a signpost
Barely visible with the gray moon waning
Route 16; a silhouette in the mountain
“Live Free or Die,”
It looks like some had made their choice

I continue on with a glimmer of hope
To come in contact with someone who can provide any clarity
Though as soon as my thought finishes, I rue what I had spoken
To hear a caravan of vehicles slowly approaching

The nearest thicket provides enough cover
To hear but not be seen
And the fortune of knowing my deep breaths
Could not be heard over their motors blaring

Dozens of jeeps, trailers, tanks, and bikes
Even three contraptions hovering above the ground!
The vehicles are painted fresh
Dark blue and gold
Peppered with slogans and chants
Even a few in French

Slowly they move, like a funeral march
Distancing themselves from torment
Into the safety of their white capped peaks

I creep out, careful to stay close to the shoulder
In case a rogue vehicle has a reason to turn back
Transfixed by what’s behind,
Indifferent to what’s in front
A stealth vehicle intercepts me,
In its crosshairs,
I’m a sitting duck at its disposal

A man bursts out of this Lantern Rouge
Camouflaged, coon-skin cap
Like a trapper marching towards the Hudson

His machine gun drawn at the ready
He shouts in a thick Quebecois tone
“You there!
What are you doing?
All citizens should know,
Trespassing the white mountain is punishment by death!”

The ice on the pines wasn’t as cold as my blood
Frozen to the spot I could barely exclaim
“D’d’don’t shoot, don’t shoot!”
I throw my hands in the air
Praying to give off the effect
A moment of true and honest surrender

Gun still raised
Unperturbed
Not blinking
Sucking out all the power I had left in me

“Billfold” he shouts “Documents now”
Somehow I had my wallet, a minor miracle I suppose
He ruffles through it, slower with each card he finds
Aghast at what the headlights reveal in the dates

“Expire, expire, expire, tous les sont expires”
He curses in French
“Where have you found these cheap knock off forgeries?”

And finally, perhaps by divine grace
He pulls out a photo, me and a smiling family of four
A sunkissed backdrop, a perfect golden hour
Emitting enough light and radiance
To cut through our pale encounter

Tears in his eyes, he suddenly realized
“C’est vrai, cest vrai
Everything my friends said
I thought they were drunk, or how you say
Defonce”

“They too found lurkers in the forest
Abandoned by time.
Mon Dieu! And you! Oui, haha!
This whole time they were right!”

“You see, I cry for your family,
I have one too
I see them, maybe once per year
A lonely life of a soldier.”

“But to you, this is nonsense, non”
You can’t begin to comprehend
The dates on your cards are still too old
To realize we’re at the bottom.”

He lights a cigarette
Takes a few puffs and breathes
“You see, my duty is on patrol,
Boring
So I have plenty of time to think.”

“They say you can destroy anything worth building
In a moment or an instant
But true evil,
Cunning evil,
How you say, waits, non
Bides its time
It festers, it rots
And then one day, everything is sulfur
The smell cannot come out.”

“Until you cut off the hand of the beast
That’s what we did.
We left - we govern ourselves
We’re figuring it out
So it goes allying with the Northern States”
“Life isn’t kind to us.
That’s okay
But we’re free and independent
To do as we please.”

“And your family, wherever they are
How you get back to them
I think….
Is only by going south.”

“See what your country has become”

“I’ll take you to the border
Please be on garde
We’re cut off from the states
News is hazy, I have no intel
With what to warn you.”

“One point for me,
A pint to my name
If you’re kind enough to give me a credit card
So my mates know I’m not insane.”

I oblige knowing these cards are useless here
Such a small token for benevolence amid this fear
I thank him as he dumps me off
On a vast open plane
In American New England
Our expansive wasteland

End of Chapter 1
entry.summary: A traveler awakens in a fractured America, encountering the seceded state of New Hampshire
